And these memories lose their meaning
 When I think of love as something new

While John is acknowledging the impact that these past memories have had on his life, he decides not to dwell on them and not to adopt the mind set of “things were so much better back then” but instead try to think about how good his life is today, not how good it was a long time ago. Looking for the good in today instead of only seeing the bad in today and thinking about how much better it could be, if only it were the good old days. Love is always something new

Some are dead and some are living
 In my life, I’ve loved them all

According to Lennon’s lifelong friend Pete Shotton, these lines refer to him and former Beatle Stuart Sutcliffe, who died unexpectedly of an aneurysm in 1962.

Incidentally, doesn’t Sutcliffe look like he’d fit right into any rock band today?

After the second verse, George Martin plays a piano solo. The reason it sounds so fast is because it is actually a clip sped up x2 from its original recording.

This speeding up of the piano is also what gives it its unique sound, sounding like a hybrid of a normal piano, and a harpsichord.

But of all these friends and lovers
 There is no one compares with you

One of Lennon’s most personal and heartfelt songs, it was written (much like McCartney’s “Paperback Writer”) as a deliberate attempt to move away from the boy-girl love songs, such as “You Can’t Do That” that dominated the Beatles' first five albums.

I think “In My Life” was the first song that I wrote that was really, consciously about my life, and it was sparked by a remark a journalist and writer in England made after In His Own Write came out. I think “In My Life” was after In His Own Write… But he said to me, ‘Why don’t you put some of the way you write in the book, as it were, in the songs? Or why don’t you put something about your childhood into the songs?’ Which came out later as “Penny Lane” from Paul – although it was actually me who lived in Penny Lane – and Strawberry Fields.
- John Lennon, All We Are Saying by David Sheff

Though I know I’ll never lose affection
 For people and things that went before
 I know I’ll often stop and think about them

At this point in his life, John had already lost several people who were close to him – his Uncle George, who raised him; his mother, Julia, who helped him pursue his dream of becoming a musician; and his close friend and bassist, Stuart Sutcliffe.

Julia in particular was never far from his thoughts.
